reviewText:
This game has a great concept. You play as a cheesy parody of a famed action hero. The game plays as a side-scrolling, 2D platformer. You can customize your character with weapons and clothing. You can also get new characters with experience. The levels are sizable. There aren't very many of them though. (I believe there are only 2 or 3.) However, they are well-designed and look great. They have multi-story buildings with roofs, and sewers below the streets. Your character can run, jump, flip, climb walls, dodge, heal, and all sorts of things. It's like Smash Bros., but with more death.

So it's fun, the controls are good, and the graphics are nice. There's just one problem: The game is online-only. If you can't find a match, you can't play. Sorry. The only single-player content is a training tutorial. This wouldn't be a problem if the game was popular... but it isn't. You won't find a match often. When you do, it'll be against fanatics of the game.

I think the worst thing is a lack of content in the game. You are forced to grind until you unlock other characters. This takes a long time due to your progress being performance-based, and the difficulty in finding a match. Which would be fine if there was some variety to the game... but there isn't. The amount of content is what you would expect from a $1 - $3 smart phone game.

reviewText:
Probably, the most profound and sensitive depiction of the internal struggle of mental patient the video-game world has seen till this day. A person of unknown identity loses control of his memories and sensual abilities and falls into a deep comatose where the memories of his childhood 90s action movies take on a whole new role. The epileptic imagery in the intro might suggest a series of seizures within the temporal lobes of the brain or even the visual cortex over exiting his visual senses making him “see” a combination of memories and hallucinations instead of detecting what surrounds him like with. It is also possible the disturbed visions and colorful memories are the results of the growth of a highly invasive and malignant tumor in the temporal lobes. The case could be similar to Dr. Oliver Sacks’ case of “the passage to India”, where a young girl could vividly see long lost memories of the India of her past after a malignant tumor had grown inside her brain. However the cause of the brain damage to the temporal lobes causing the memories to reemerge are not important, what is to be noted is that these distorted visions of the past brings a certain comfort to the patient. The minds tend to like to compensate for lacks with other things. So the patient while not remembering the exact names of his childhood heroes, his brain renamed them in a way that would sound soothing to him. The struggle lies between recognizing that the visions are mere hallucinations and to face a cold reality of pain or indulge in the fantasy dream world his mind created for him to make him feel happy, like a child again. The visions intermingled with the dreams of a possible comatose has somewhat of a Jungian feel to it. The many characters and objects of his past somehow symbolize many of the figures in his life that he enjoyed the presence of. The characters ad objects are in some way his Jungian dream archetypes. Hailey is the archetype of the child representing his innocence, Thelma his desire to become a hero and achieve glory like his role models, Lance as the father figure he always wished for, Shur foo as the sage etc. Being among his dream archetypes and experiencing a sense a control and belonging pulls him constantly further into his comatose. Eventually, just like Alexander Luria’s “man with a shattered world” , he couldn’t distinguish memories and hallucination and the dreams would repeat themselves over and over again with the same characters his mind created.
The brilliance in this game lies in the fact that it can make us feel the torment of the patient, how such a playful and funny and conforting game could seem more interesting than reality but details such as the Jungian archetypes and the visual and auditif seizures remind us that what can be seen is but a stew illusions. And at that time we can feel the pain the patient feels to be forever stuck in this looping fantasy world and that he will probably never see the “real” world ever again. The pain, the feels.

Bravo arrowhead.

The game is one big action movie inspired hack and slash/brawler relying solely on multiplayer, which frankly, is a very tight community (Sometimes making finding games very difficult). Characters have their own abilites and one-liners, like you'd expect. Costumization is varied, but only cosmetically. There are only a few weapon types and the base weapon is basically the only weapon you can have if you don't buy weapon skins (bought with in game money)

At the end of the day, TSE is a great little timewaster to play with friends and mess around with the stunts and action-coolness-explosions-heavyrock, And it isn't much else. But because I picked it up for 2,50, I can say it was well worth the time I invested into it. If it is ever on sale again, it's a must buy, if not, you can do without it.
7/10

reviewText:
Developed by the makers of Magika, Arrowhead, The Showdown Affect is a side-scrolling, action movie inspired online multiplayer brawler. I saw the trailer for this game before it was released and thought it looked really fun and seeing it scored only a 67 on metacritic puzzled me a bit. The Showdown Effect is not a bad game, but it's metacritic rating is deserved.

On the up side, The Showdown Effect does deliver the action they advertise in the video so if you watched the trailer and thought it looked fun chances are you will enjoy it somewhat at the very least. The gameplay is only average though and I feel like the developers spend more time and energy on the game's theme.

There are microtransactions in this game but they appear to be exclusively cosmetic and game changing unlocks cannot be purchased with currency in anyway. I am still a little bit offended that microtransactions were introduced to this retail game.

What's lacking in this game is any longevity. My impression is that after you got your chuckles from the theme and played a few rounds you've seen all the game has to offer. There are additional characters to unlock but they are largely all the same with the exception of a single special ability.

In my two hours of gameplay I did experience a few non-crashing bugs - weapons not reloading when they should and my screen blanking out a few times.

The Showdown Effect is an exclusely multiplayer game so unless you can find people to play online then this game is effectively useless. There is no bot matches or local multiplayer to speak of. I was able to find matches for about 2 hours but they were pretty slim and my session with this game was ended due to the lack of populated servers.

Even though it's a pretty reasonable game, I can't recommend getting this because as gameplay goes it only average and there's no guarantee this game won't soon be a client with no server to connect to.

Score: 6/10

reviewText:
The most under rated game on Steam.

Be warned, there is no controller support and the controls take A LOT of getting used to, but once you start to get even a rudimentary understanding of the controls and the pacing of the matches it then becomes one of the fastest and most brutal multiplayer experiences you can get. The ode to 80's and 90's nostalgia is just the beautiful wrapping the game comes in, and it works. I always thought a good competitive Super Smasher Brothers type game was just what the PC needed and this game delivered.
I even waited until it had been out for awhile to make sure that there was a good foundation of a community,(yes it's only playable online PVP) so that I wouldn't get stuck with a game I can't play, and from what I've seen they are a great bunch of people to play with. Only downside is that most of them are deadly good at the game by now....lol
The only thing I didn't like was the fact that it offered an in game store for items that were available only for cash only when all items should be unlockable through the grind.
All round great game if you're looking for that new competitive type experience, definitely worth the price and a must have if it goes anywhere close to 50% off.

reviewText:
The Showdown Effect
A Game that had great potential


Visual: 8/10
The game has a very stylish art-style, that generally looks good. The only part of the games visuals I didn't enjoy was the characters, because they look like plastic. The game is succeeding to give you that 80's action feel, since they have their obligatory Terminator parody. I also need to point out that the menu literally looks like an 80's TV screen.


Sound: 7/10
Showdown has an explosive action theme song that really pumps you up for the action, but sadly there is no song like that once you enter a round. The sound effects are fine, but it's mostly guns firing so there isn't much to say about that.
The voice-acting is very funny since they do have that bootleg Terminator, which creates some funny moments when playing the game.


Gameplay: 7/10
The gameplay is fun and fast. It's a 8-player deathmatch game that lasts 5 minutes. Once you're done with those 5 minutes it transitions into a last man standing kind of thing (note: the last man standing is not the winner. The winner is the person with the highest amount of kills.) which changes the pacing slightly as you aren't all that willing to die.

There are some unlockable guns and characters, but you should be able to get everything by a couple of hours of gametime. I would've enjoyed more customization but they probably did this to keep the game balanced. All in all the gameplay is very enjoyable.


DLC: 8/10
The DLC in Showdown is kinda useless. The reason for this is that they are reskins of weapons, or hats. I enjoy this alot since it keeps the game fair and balanced.


Money/Time: 1/10
The game doesn't cost much and I enjoyed it very much, but the game is now dead. There is nobody online nowadays so just stay away from the game. It's a shame that the developers (spearhead studios, creators of Magicka.) updated the game once then left, and are now working on Magicka 2. Get Magicka 2 instead, you'll most likely have a better time there...

This is a kinetic multiplayer deathmatch game, done in 2.5D. The movement in this game is great, you feel it control of your character at all times, and can use dives tackles, dodges, jumps, wall jumps, wall hangs, flips and slides to navigate the wonderfully detailed levels. As for the combat, you have seven basic weapon types, all of which behave differently, and you can bring two into a fight, so theres plenty of mix and matching and experimentation to do. Or you can only use your fists if you like. Different characters have different personalities, and also different special abilities like temporary invulnerability or  health on kill, and so far they all seem well balanced.

Of course, the combat goes hand in hand with the movement, and its all about using all these weapons and abilites on the move while dodging enemy fire and by god it all combines into one hell of a game, it feels great to dodge artfully around a room chopping up enemies with a sword, or winning a match by tossing your empty gun at a fleeing opponent or gracefully sliding under an incoming rocket while blasting the shooter with your pistol or dive tackling an enemny off a cliff just as theyre about to land the killing blow.

Its just great fun! A more than worthwhile investment at 10 euro.

This is a kinetic multiplayer deathmatch game, done in 2.5D. The movement in this game is great, you feel it control of your character at all times, and can use dives tackles, dodges, jumps, wall jumps, wall hangs, flips and slides to navigate the wonderfully detailed levels. As for the combat, you have seven basic weapon types, all of which behave differently, and you can bring two into a fight, so theres plenty of mix and matching and experimentation to do. Or you can only use your fists if you like. Different characters have different personalities, and also different special abilities like temporary invulnerability or  health on kill, and so far they all seem well balanced.

Of course, the combat goes hand in hand with the movement, and its all about using all these weapons and abilites on the move while dodging enemy fire and by god it all combines into one hell of a game, it feels great to dodge artfully around a room chopping up enemies with a sword, or winning a match by tossing your empty gun at a fleeing opponent or gracefully sliding under an incoming rocket while blasting the shooter with your pistol or dive tackling an enemny off a cliff just as theyre about to land the killing blow.

Its just great fun! A more than worthwhile investment at 10 euro.

My computer isn't the best or the newest, but I run things like Call of Duty, Europa Universalis, Civilization V, and Total War: Shogun 2 without much of a problem; so the fact that it takes 20-30 seconds for something like a menu click to register is godawful. Graphics aren't great. Character models are boxy and there's an unacceptable amount of blur. Projectiles have visible polygons.
